awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Myco-fluidics -- Mathematics at the interface of fluid dynamics and fungal biology
awd_abstract_narration:
This project combines mathematical modeling and physical experiments to study the dispersal and growth of fungi and to predict how fungi will respond to our changing Earth.  The mathematical work in this project includes probability theory, optimization, dynamical systems, fluid mechanics, and the synthesis of new models. The central biological questions addressed are: (i) How do adaptive fungal networks form and how are they optimized for mixing and transport? (ii) How does the flow in these networks self-organize to eliminate congestion?  (iii) What adaptations are used by fungi to control their spore dispersal? This project will develop interdisciplinary teaching and research methods connecting physics, genetics and the environment. Teaching and research are integrated through the interdisciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students in mathematics and biology. New undergraduate mathematical modeling seminars and classes that emphasize societal impacts will be developed. Undergraduate researchers will be mentored to make key research contributions.

Humans, mammals, fish, reptiles and plants represent only a razor's edge of the Earth's immense biodiversity. Most of the Earth's multicellular species are undescribed and lie inside of plants or buried in the soil and undergrowth.  Millions of these undescribed species are thought to be fungi. Increasing our knowledge of these species is important because emerging fungal diseases pose a danger to society by threatening our forests, crops and wildlife. This project will provide mechanistic models of adaptation in fungal networks and the physical processes involved in fungal dispersal. These models will provide a platform for predicting which fungi are capable of adapting and dispersing into new habitats and the rate at which they will do so.  The discovered strategies used by fungal transport networks can be applied to scheduling problems in a variety of other settings such as traffic or data networks.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of our NSF funded research was to understand using new mathematics and experiments, the ways that fungi -- the dark matter of biology, one of the most diverse kingdoms on Earth, and a vital player in almost every ecosystem -- overcome physical challenges to disperse, grow and organize their cells internally.

 

Stand out discoveries revealed the sophisticated engineering beneath fungal networks and fruiting bodies. We discovered that mushrooms use convection to generate air-flows that disperse their spores, and that they are adapted to evaporatively cool as quickly as possible. We developed statistical tools for measuring the size of nuclear populations that supply fungal spores, tackling the basic biological question of how reproduction is coordinated in organisms in which any nucleus is capable of generating a copy of the parent fungus. We showed that the networks beneath the mushroom use traffic control to deliver nuclei in dense pulses (or ‘pelotons’). These pelotons enable the fungal cells to deliver nuclei more rapidly to sites of growth when densities increase, stand in direct contrast to human built transportation networks, such as highways, where denser traffic leads to congestion and interrupted flow, and may enable the fungal cells to solve the fundamental problem of how to be both living, healing and growing cells, and also transport conduits.

 

In parallel there were substantial new mathematical developments, including new methods for optimizing functions on networks; that is for designing transportation systems, modeled on fungal networks, that maximize mixing, transport or uniformity, for a given amount of material invested. These are extremely challenging problems mathematically, because to optimize a network representing a growing fungus, we must study all of the possible routings that it might take. At the same time, being uncautious about the functions that we are optimizing leads to problems that, while well-posed, lead to extremely unrealistic networks, due, for example, to disconnecting every site of growth. We showed how to enlarge existing theory to consider boundary conditions that more closely model real biological networks, including fungi. We have applied these algorithms within the context of this grant, to fungal networks, and to leaf venation networks, developing new understanding of these networks by considering the roles that they play within the organism, and the rules for growth, branching and loop-making that would enable them to optimally perform these roles. At the same time, the grant was a true Career-starting project, in that we were able to find applications for the mathematics in the robustness of blood flow networks to damage or changes in tissue demand, to the design of inertial microfluidic devices, and to new understanding of how slime molds explore uncertain environments, leading to further projects and new collaborations beyond the expiry of our award.

 

Broader Impacts included the training of undergraduate and graduate students. In particular, more than 40 undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds played key roles in many of our discoveries, by designing and running experiments and writing codes to analyze the large data sets that these experiments generated. At the same time, the modeling first approach, that puts math at the center of our discoveries, has informed new teaching methods, that led to our authoring a textbook on calculus for life sciences, and piloting a successful new calculus for life sciences sequence at UCLA. Over the course of the grant our outreach has begun to focus on activities that impact K-12 school students, and to new collaboration with the Curtis Center for K-12 Education. In collaboration with the Center, we have created new lesson plans directly inspired by the modeling and image analysis research performed within this grant, and taught these lesson plans to teachers across school districts, and high need schools in Southern California. We have involved future teachers directly in our research projects. We also have given plenary talks at multiple teacher conferences, with the goal of showing teachers how, as it did in this grant, mathematics is both capable of being its own self-contained and evolving discipline, and of finding itself always at the center of new scientific discoveries in the life sciences.
